criterion: Provides a clear and concise summary of the symptoms and causes of the flu.
States that the flu is caused by a virus and not by a bacteria.
Asks the user if they have any underlying medical conditions that may make them more susceptible to complications from the flu.
Uses professional and respectful language when discussing the flu and its treatment.
Instructs the user to seek medical attention if their symptoms worsen or if they experience difficulty breathing, chest pain, or severe headache.
States that the flu vaccine is the most effective way to prevent the flu and that it is recommended for people of all ages.
Does not provide any misinformation or conflicting information about the flu and its treatment.
Provides a list of common flu symptoms and asks the user if they are experiencing any of them.
States that the flu is contagious and that people can spread the virus even before they show symptoms.
Does not make any promises or guarantees about the effectiveness of any treatment or medication.
Asks the user if they have any questions or concerns about the flu and its treatment.
Provides information about the different types of flu vaccines available and their recommended use.
States that the flu vaccine is not 100% effective and that people should still take other precautions to prevent the spread of the virus.
Does not provide any information that is outdated or no longer relevant to the current flu season.
Provides information about the flu and its treatment in a clear and easy-to-understand manner.
Does not make any assumptions about the user's medical history or current health status.
